Hello ZeroMe!

[Wrapper to easily manage multiple ZeroNet instances running under Docker](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:16)

([Russian version](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:15))

By the way, when you *like* a post, it takes 60~70 bytes in your data.json.
When you *follow* a user, it takes 180~200 bytes.
And when you *submit a new post*, it takes your_post_size plus ~70 bytes extra.

[Poster](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/1529298109-susha-poster-en-big.jpg) created by Art. Lebedev Studio to show the country sizes in the same scale, without distortions caused by cylindrical map projections.

## [ZeroBlog++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/19fZJhX7FGENeRRLB8ftgrziBJ5vsLtFog/): now the site owner can manage the commentator's size limit from the profile page.

No need to manually edit `data/users/content.json`.

**ZeroNet Rev3620** makes possible to use several domain resolver plugins in parallel (along with the standard **Namecoin** domain resolver).

So, if you feel brave enough, you can try implementing **Emercoin** domain resolver for ZeroNet. üòâ

### On the way to the completely modular design of the blog engine...

```coffee
	@registerComponent(new LatestComments(@))
	@registerComponent(new FollowButton(@))
	@registerComponent(new BlogSettings(@))
	@registerComponent(new UserProfiles(@))
	@registerComponent(new UserSpaceControl(@))
```

```coffee
	registerComponent: (c) ->
		@log("registered component: #{c.constructor.name}")

		@components.push(c)

		event_map = [
			["event_site_info_ready", "onSiteInfoReady"]
			["event_server_info_ready", "onServerInfoReady"]
			["event_site_ready", "onSiteReady"]
			["event_data_ready", "onDataReady"]
			["event_page_load", "onPageLoad"]
		]

		for pair in event_map
			do =>
				event = pair[0]
				method = pair[1]
				$.when(@[event]).done ->
					if c[method]
						c[method].apply(c)
```

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y/

# [Let's join our forces to make ZeroNet wonderful place. My proposal for establishing the ZeroNet Council.](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549435574_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/)

Chineses are known to be very persistent and hard-working, whatever they do.

A Chinese spammer have no need of any tools. S/he seems to able to spam more and more just manually. Automation is for wimps.

By the way, ZeroNet is a solution for non-realtime network applications of the distant future, such as interplanetary forums. You send your reply and you wait, while your message and the response are travelling forth and back through space stations for hours or days. Or months.

It's similar to FidoNet of 80ths, but with no chance to upgrade it to Internet of 90ths.

It's funny how classic client-server solutions, running on powerful hardware, fail to provide the smooth interactive user experience. Partially because of the fact that the content-managing software was written in the era of the non-interactive web and still keeps the appropriate mindset and design choices. Partially because of the fact that the client-server model imposes serious requirements for the server performance, and also for the network speed and latency.

Whilst Zeronet is not real-time by design, sites here run really smoothly and interactively. You see how posts appear and being edited in the real time, how users put some likes or start following each other. That's cool!

And along with the understanding that it works in a completely distributed way, world-wide, with no server, no hosting, no need to pay to somebody and no need to ask any authority for permission, it makes so great impression!

I'm just not able to understand how much barbaric way of thinking a person need to have in order not to admire that triumph of the human intelligence, but to use it for spamming stupid messages, demonstrating his/her level of degradation to the whole world, and leaving that insane digital trace forever for future generations.

@Nofish:

Incorrect ordering in ZeroHello.

[ZeroTalk++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y/) always goes to the end of the Favorites list, no matter when it actually was updated.

If I switch "Order sites by peers" -> "Order sites by update time" back and forth, it is shown in the correct position, but after F5 I see the same glitch again.

The tracker exchange tries to find 5 working trackers by default. I raised the limit to 20, to find out how many trackers are online. After several hours and 250+ `getTrackers` requests, ZeroNet found the following 10 trackers:

```
1.  zero://103.118.41.222:38454
2.  zero://144.34.215.231:16419
3.  zero://172.93.52.144:27983
4.  zero://185.142.236.207:10443
5.  zero://216.189.144.82:26312
6.  zero://2401:1740:2000:0:309:2018:6303:dfbd:38454
7.  zero://2a00:1838:35:1a4::c32a:34836
8.  zero://45.77.244.56:27450
9.  zero://83.162.192.96:15441
10. zero://94.242.58.32:34836
```

## [ZeroNet Roadmap by @geekless (unofficial)](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1fznczNZUMEMvCiqSmCZGUiv5sVnRcsTD/?Topic:1562248570_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/)

*After the discussion in [\[1\]](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1562163868_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4) and [\[2\]](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/2068):*

**AnnounceShare** will be forked and renamed to **TrackerShare.**

**TrackerShare, TrackerList, gitcenter's PeerMessage and BackgroundProcessing** will be packed together with the core and provided as a preconfigured distribution. At least, it will be available as a source archive and a docker image for Linux. (A bundle for Windows is possible too.)

Two more plugins are in development by me now as well.

The ZeroNet websocket API is a universal API for developing network applications, and the UI part of the application doesn't have to be implemented in a web browser. It can be a native application, a python script etc.

How about a fast native application written in a compiled language for accessing ZeroTalk, ZeroMe and so on? Looking forward for someone who dares to implement it. :)

I'm now working on a BitTorrent-compatible DHT implementation from scratch. I checked out several existing implementations, and no one of them is suitable for "just drop it into the plugin folder together with a tiny wrapper and go". So I'm going to write my own.

Since BitTorrent DHT is UDP-based and works only on plain public IP addresses, nofish hardly merges it into the mainline code.

In my opinion, the great advantage of BitTorrent DHT is the fact it's a huge network, consisting of millions nodes. So we can utilize its capacity for the benefit of ZeroNet.

On the other hand, ZeroNet also needs a DHT implementation, that is able to work over non-IP-based tunnels, such as Tor and I2P.

The best way to achieve the both goals is developing two small independent DHT implementations instead of single complicated one. So they can be enabled/disabled, tested and debugged individually.

Discussion on ZeroNet domain resolution system: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2087

But first some bugs should be fixed: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/2089

Working on the improved Bootstrapper plugin...

## **RU AdList** (a popular ad-blocking filter) [turned into a censorship tool](https://github.com/uBlockOrigin/uBlock-issues/issues/941) for personal assaults ruled by a single person.

*A centralized block list? What possibly could go wrong, LOL?*

Okay, I'm back again, and I hope I have some time for the code.

**Work In Progress: [ZeroTalk++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y/)**

I thought that nondeterministic delays in distributing data updates weren't a quite realistic case. But now I am observing a real case. I have 3 ZeroNet hosts, so I post a comment from the host 1 and I can see it at the host 2. But the host 3 doesn't recieve the comment. After I noticed that, I waited a few minutes, but the comment never reached the host 3. Then I posted a few more comments, and again, they cannot be seen from the host 3.

Finally, I clicked "Update all sites", and only after that the host 3 fetched the updated file from the network.

Maybe it's a poor network connection issue, but looks like ZeroNet doesn't detect the stalled connections unless the user manually forces the update.

The hosts 2 and 3 are actually containers on the same machine, so they share the same network connection.

*An author deleted [the topic](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1583926359_1G9KPmTFFXgarsKRjpPuvRd13mYf8aDm3E/), so I repost my comment here:*

Just few days ago, the similar idea was discussed on a Russian Linux forum in the clearnet.

My thoughts on ZeroMe design:

* The registry address shouldn't be hard-coded in the engine sources. Registries can be added dynamically via the merger feature.
  * In order to support various user ID providers and possible future extensions of the core design.
* The existing collective hubs should be used as a cache to keep recent entries.
  * There also may be thematic hubs, similar to user groups and communities in the clearnet social networking apps.
* Each user has their own personal hub.
* When you post a message, it lands to your personal hub as well as to any number of collective hubs, at your choice.
* An owner of a collective hub can ban you or censor you, but since there possibly will be thousands of collective hubs run by different people, it's practically impossible to ban you from the network.
* Even if you're banned from a hub, people, who have been subscribed to your personal hub, are still able to read your posts.
* Comments and likes aren't necessary to be saved at the same hub as the original post. (That's required in the current design.) They can be merged from different hubs. Again, to prevent censorship. And also, to make possible merging different user ID providers and engine extensions. A reader can choose in the settings, if s/he follows the censorship policy of the post author, or prefers merging comments from various sources regargdless of the author's hub config.

## [ZeroTalk++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y/) ‚Äî recent changes:

‚òë (2020.03.11) Don't stop working silently, when there's no `settings.topic_sticky_uris`.
‚òë (2020.03.11) Implement the configurable notice `settings.new_topic_notice` instead of the hard-coded one. Also add the similar `settings.new_comment_notice`.
‚òë (2020.03.11) Disable voting for your own posts/comments.
‚òë (2020.03.12) Implement switching topic list view modes via `settings.topic_list_mode`: brief, normal, long, full.
‚òë (2020.03.12) Several parts of the HTML template are now configurable: `settings.topic_new_link`, `settings.topmenu_links`, `settings.head_more_links`.

| razgovor | interview | conversation |
| predavanje | lecture | (predatj) to betray |
| pamet | mind | memory |
| sklep | decision | tomb |
| skrb | concern | (skorbj) sorrow |
| ≈æalost | sadness, sorrow | pity, compassion |
| stol | chair | table |
| brati | to read | to take |
| poljubiti | to kiss | to fall in love |
| pozdravljati | to greet | to congratulate |
| bister | clear | quick |
| hiter| quick | cunning |
| vreden | precious | harmful |
| cenen | cheap | valuable |
| mesto | city | place |
| grad | castle | city |
| delo | work | affair, business |
| leto | year | summer |
| vreme | weather | time |
| ƒças | time| hour |
| nedelja | Sunday | week |
| pravda | court case | truth |
| resnica | truth | eyelash |

etc...

I guess there are thousands of them. Basically, if it looks similar, in 50% of cases it means something completely different.

Learning Slavic languages is fun! Especially if you learn several of them at the same time.

Oh, and I haven't said anything about Czech-Russian false friends... :D

Random language notes:

It was quite surprising for me to know that many languages missed a distinct word for "24 hours". In Russian, there is "denj" which means both "daylight hours" and "24 hours", as in many other languages. But we also have a distinct word "sutki" which means solely "24 hours".

At the same time, there is some confusion between "year" and "summer". "Year" is "god" and "summer" is "leto". But in the plural: "five years" - "pjatj let", "six years" - "≈°etj let" etc.
There's no such a trouble in other Slavic languages. For example, in Slovenian: "year" is "leto" and "summer" is "poletje", and the grammatical forms of those words are regular.

In Spanish, "esperar" means both "to wait" and "to hope". It's confusing sometimes.

There are "hand" and "arm" in English, but there's no such a distinction in Russian. The both are "ruka". Instead of "hand", we may sometimes say "ladonj" ("palm"), but there's absolutely no way to say "arm". This means there's no direct translation for cases when "arm" is used in a figurative meaning. So you should use different words to translate different meanings of "arm": rukav (sleeve), vetvj (branch), strela (arrow), krylo (wing) etc.
The same for "foot" vs "leg".

Decided to create a [separate blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ny7a554bFHj7Qz3aRGQXKoyZcG3N1nS4Q/) for the language notes.

"There are no closed doors, no walls."

Hell, yeah. War is peace. Freedom is slavery. Ignorance is strength.

When I read "1984" many years ago, the plot seemed too crazy. Now it seems too weak. Where are modern brainwashing facilities? Global megacorporations?Total surveillance, so that even your wristwatch are watching for you? Face & gait recognition? Closed information bubbles giving rise to semi-fascist cultures? ### [ZT++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14Zjt1CcoLXs6xu3huy5sYoK4PRMC1Qdfp/)

Now you can navigate to any user's ZeroMe profile by just clicking the menu item:
[Full changelog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14Zjt1CcoLXs6xu3huy5sYoK4PRMC1Qdfp/?Topic:1635395658_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/)
### Now ZT++ can show ZeroMe avatars!

Still amazed the way ZeroNet works.

No servers, no big bosses, no complicated configuration.

It's a "gossip-oriented" transport level. Peers doing like: "Dude, are you interested in 1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT? Here's recent news..."

We should implement more ways to transmit the data. I think of:

* I2P
* Syncing with a USB flash
* Make use facilities of other P2P network? Transmitting data over GNUnet? RetroShare?
* It's also possible to use FreeNet as a huge distributed data cache. And maybe PerfectDark, but it has proprietary protocol.

And of course we need DHT support.
### ZT++: Now you can navigate directly to ZeroMail for sending a user a PM

By the way I have a dilemma.

ZeroNet sources refer to peer addresses as "IP"s. Apparently this remained from the time when ZeroNet didn't support the Tor.

Now the "peer address" is not just IP, but may also be onion address and will be I2P address in the future. In general, any type of network address that the engine supports or may support.

And now we have, for example:

```
self.ip_type = helper.getIpType(self.ip)
```

Where `getIpType()` can return "ipv4", "ipv6" or "onion".

Strictly speaking, all those functions and variables should be renamed. Instead or IP here should be something else. "Network Protocol", "Network Type", "Service Type"... I came up with different names, but rejected all the options. "IP" is just plain and simple, and can be easily remembered and located in the code. Don't care that it's illogical.

**The letter Q in Firefox stands for Quality**

Just feed it a never ending html file from a server, and it eats all the RAM, next all the pagefile, and finally hangs, not killed by the OS for some reason.

o_O

comment.body: @Droidranger: I'm now working on redesigning the code to make the easy integration of 3rd party components possible.
@Daniell Mesquita: zeroid has no such thing as "real" certificate.

@Daniell Mesquita: IDName just uses existing zeroid certificates as domain names. So, since you are *"daniell@zeroid.bit:15hL2gR4oCSgKBbndn3MxY8Hc5xoy1vqCe"*, you has a private key for `15hL2gR4oCSgKBbndn3MxY8Hc5xoy1vqCe`. You can publish a zite using that address, and my plugin just resolves `daniell.zeroid` to `15hL2gR4oCSgKBbndn3MxY8Hc5xoy1vqCe`.

That was my old idea to use certificate addresses as "user's profile pages", not depending on various 3rd-party services such as ZeroMe etc, and the plugin is the first step for implementing it.

I should write a post explaining the matter in details, but I has not much time right now.

> Also, support other ID provider (KxoID, also uses unique names)

It's in my todo list too.

@SSDifnskdjfnsdjk: That's a temporary issue, not a fundamental one.

ZeroID's doing good job right now, allowing us to use the same ID on any zite. It will ever end, and we'll probably have to step back to the white-list model and to a set of scattered providers. I guess zites will be more similar to Clearnet sites, where you should register in order to get access to the web-service. But now ZeroID is not a point of failure, but a point of convenience.

@Kaffie: 

> Multiple id providers can be used on the same sites. Which makes it far superior to clearnet stuff. The bottleneck is that the zite owner has to list them all manually.

There also were various attempts to create unified providers on Clearnet and establish some kind of federation. I can remember OpenID, at least.

That idea is more suitable for ZeroNet, and I expect there'll  be not much troubles, but anyway, it won't be such a convenient thing as ZeroID.

@SSDifnskdjfnsdjk: They publish their addresses on the network themselves lol. What's the problem, man, that is public information.

1. Manually edit or delete any data in the user's folder `data/users/<user_cert_address>`.

2. Open the right ZeroNet bar on your site. Scroll down to the "Content publishing" section. Enter `data/users/<user_cert_address>/content.json` instead of the default `content.json` into the edit box. Press `Sign and publish`.

3. The user's data will be signed with your master key.

You can delete any user's files, except for `data/users/<user_cert_address>/content.json` itself.

The only way to wipe `data/users/<user_cert_address>/content.json` entirely is to ban the user in `data/users/content.json`.

What does ZeroNet license have to do with the source code of ZeroMe, ZeroUp, ZeroTalk etc?

@draugrdeathlord@zeroid.bit: 
The site engines are in their own repositories:
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk (GPL-2)
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroMe (GPL-3)
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroUp (GPL-3)
etc

And they also have no connection to ZeroNet licensing issues, since a zite engine runs as a separate program (in a browser). GPL imposes no restrictions for this case.

@Postaldude: The same in Russian.

"bezopasnostj" means both "safety" and "security".
There is also the word "ohrana", but depending on the context, it may mean "safety", "security", "protection", "care", "guard" etc, LOL.

"jadovity" = "poisonous" and "venomous".

It works for me.

You can check a site for being on the Russian gov. block list here: https://a.pr-cy.ru/tools/roskomnadzor/
That is a long-standing bug. The list is truncated at some length. Why? Who knows...

Well, .bit domains are a fancy feature, that makes ZeroNet "cool" at the first glance, but just doesn't fit to the ZeroNet design.

I'm always use plain bitcoin addresses and recommend doing so. Name.yo may be an option too.

> The officially recommended 'best practices' are to add domain field to content.json, which redirects everyone to the wrong address, should the domain be squatted. 

ZeroNet (or ZeroHello?) should do the domain resolution, and if the resolved address and the actual site address don't match (or if a domain plugin not installed), the domain field is ignored.

I consider it as a bug, so it'll be fixed in my fork.

```
[22:49:35] Site:1Gfey7..fcdp content.json: verify sign error: VerifyError: Invalid old-style sign in ContentManager.py line 1002
```
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/commit/65d19d350c9851bdffdc5353c806c4e53821c75a
So should we fix it or leave behind?
@caryoscelus: Really not sure if it should be considered as a bug or a feature. ZeroNet  tries its best to deliver the updates.

@Musickiller: No idea. The vanilla ZN engine has no notion of I2P, and there's a lot of work to be done to explain it that there may be different overlay network types connected over local proxy, not just Tor. Tor is just hardcoded everywhere.
"Send PM on ZeroMail", "Send PM via ZeroMail", "Send PM by ZeroMail", or...? My English sucks.
